name: Painted Dunes
description: Unique, colorful volcanic dunes created by oxidation of ash, providing a stark contrast to the surrounding dark lava beds and cinder cones.
tips: Climb the Cinder Cone to get an elevated, 360-degree view of the dunes
Explore different focal lengths to capture patterns in the volcanic landscape
Look for the contrast between dark gray scoria and the vibrant colors of the dunes

name: Cinder Cone Summit
description: Provides spectacular bird’s-eye views of the grand volcanic panorama created by the Fantastic Lava Beds and the Painted Dunes. Reaching the summit changes the perspective of both volcanic features significantly.
tips: Use both wide-angle and telephoto lenses.
Time your visit early or late in the day to avoid heat distortion waves that occur at mid-day.
Consider staying for night sky images over the landscape.

name: Lassen Peak Trail
description: The summit of the largest plug dome volcano in the world, standing at over 10,000 ft. and offering views as the southernmost Cascade in the range.
tips: Be prepared for 43 switchbacks and nearly 2,000 ft. of elevation gain
The summit is ideal for 360-degree views of the surrounding landscape

name: Manzanita Lake
description: A classic viewpoint offering a clear vista of Lassen Peak and Chaos Crags, perfect for reflections and astrophotography.
tips: The core of the Milky Way rises directly behind Lassen Peak in the summer months
Scout the lake shore during the day to find a spot with an uninterrupted view of the peaks
Wait for golden light during sunset, which can bathe the peaks in a warm glow for a very short duration

name: Fantastic Lava Beds (Ground Level)
description: Viewed from the parking lot beside the Cinder Cone trailhead, the black, blocky piles of lava stretch into Butte Lake, creating a wall several stories high.
tips: Capture the ground-level perspective immediately upon exiting your vehicle at the trailhead to contrast with summit views.

name: Chaos Crags
description: Dramatic rock formations that provide a stunning backdrop, especially when overlooking a frozen, snow-covered Manzanita Lake.
tips: Capture the dramatic skies over the crags
Winter provides a unique frozen foreground when shooting from the lake level

name: Cinder Cone Trail (Painted Dunes)
description: A unique volcanic landscape featuring the vibrant, colorful natural lava beds known as the Painted Dunes and views of the Fantastic Lava Flows.
tips: Soft morning light is essential to bring out the vibrant colors of the dunes
Climb to the top of the cinder cone for a panoramic view down into the crater and over the lava beds

name: Cinder Cone Slopes
description: The steep, dark gray slopes of the Cinder Cone volcano provide a dramatic backdrop for minimalist photography.
tips: Look for isolated trees growing on the slopes to serve as a strong subject for minimalist compositions
Late-season snow can provide high-contrast textures against the dark volcanic soil
Be prepared for difficult footing on loose scoria when setting up your tripod

name: Painted Dunes (Ground Level)
description: From the trail, the dunes appear as smooth, undulating hills dotted with sporadic trees, offering a sense of scale before the climb.
tips: Use this perspective to show the transition from the base to the colorful details visible from higher elevations.

name: Ridge Lakes Trail
description: A secluded alpine lake featuring turquoise-blue waters surrounded by towering peaks.
tips: Shoot on a clear, sunny summer day to capture the deep turquoise color of the water

name: Sulphur Works
description: An easily accessible geothermal area featuring bubbling mud pots and steam vents near the southwest entrance.
tips: Focus on close-up shots of bubbling mud pots to capture unique textures
Be aware of shifting steam which can obscure your lens or create interesting atmospheric effects
Use faster shutter speeds to freeze the motion of bubbling mud

name: Painted Dunes (from Summit)
description: The summit height reveals bright orange, gold, and yellow dusting on the beige and ash-brown landscape, showing the oxidized ash patterns.
tips: Notice how shifting daylight affects the shapes and colors of the dunes.
Use a telephoto lens to isolate interesting shapes and patterns.

name: Lassen Peak
description: The park's namesake active stratovolcano offering panoramic views stretching across the park and dramatic 'last light' opportunities.
tips: The summit offers 360-degree views for wide-angle landscape shots
Capture the rays of the setting sun layered over the peak and the valley
Use moonlight to illuminate the peak for night shots

name: Manzanita Lake Trail
description: A classic alpine lake view where Lassen Peak reflects in the water and glows during the evening hours.
tips: The west side of the lake offers the best vantage points to see the peak glow at sunset

name: Kings Creek Meadow Viewpoint
description: A popular spot featuring a meandering creek over lush grass with Lassen Peak in the background.
tips: Don't ignore popular spots; your specific time of day and weather conditions will make your image unique.

name: Bumpass Hell Trail
description: The park's largest active hydrothermal area, featuring boiling pools, bubbling mud pots, and steaming vents.
tips: Stay on designated trails to safely photograph the delicate geothermal features
Capture the contrast between the turquoise boiling pools and the surrounding earth

name: Kings Creek Meadow (Elevated Turnout)
description: A turnout at a higher elevation provides a view looking down at the creek meanders, making the meadow look smaller and showing a different scale.
tips: Compare this elevated view with the ground-level shot to show the change in scale.

name: Kings Creek Falls
description: A stunning waterfall surrounded by greenery that provides a lush contrast to the park's volcanic terrain.
tips: Recommended for an early start to catch the soft morning light
Use a tripod for long exposure shots of the falling water

name: Upper Kings Creek Meadow
description: A stunning alpine meadow on the southeast side of Lassen Peak that catches the very first light of the day.
tips: Simply pull over and set up; first light hitting the peak and meadow is the primary subject
Arrive early to beat the mid-morning crowds

name: Dixie Fire Aftermath (Southwestern Entrance)
description: Sobering views of charred tree skeletons following the 2021 Dixie Fire.
tips: Stay on the road for safety due to snags and falling branches.
Use a telephoto lens to close in on the blackened forest remains.
Try using burnt trees as natural frames.

name: Butte Lake
description: A striking turquoise volcanic lake influenced by the Fantastic Lava Flows, offering a less busy alternative to main park sites.
tips: Kayaking or paddleboarding provides unique angles of the lava flows merging into the water
Hike the Bathtub Lake Trail for elevated vantage points over Butte Lake

name: Dixie Fire Aftermath (Beyond Sulphur Works)
description: A turnout about a half-mile beyond Sulphur Works showing parallel black trees standing like toothpicks and the fire's proximity to the Visitor Center.
tips: Look for patterns in the parallel standing trees.
Note the contrast between the burnt foreground and the green hills in the background.

name: Brokeoff Mountain Trail
description: An underrated summit trail providing panoramic views and a clear sightline to the sunset hitting Lassen Peak's highest elevations.
tips: The summit is arguably the best spot in the park for sunset photography of Lassen Peak

name: Terrace, Shadow, & Cliff Lakes Trail
description: A trail featuring three distinct alpine lakes, each offering unique reflections and surrounding peak views.
tips: Each lake has a different character; explore all three for various alpine photography compositions

name: Lassen Peak Highway
description: The main 34-mile scenic byway reaching 8,511 ft., providing views of Emerald Lake, Lake Helen, and various volcanic landmarks.
tips: Stop at the road summit for high-elevation perspectives of the park
Check road status as snow often keeps the highway closed into July

name: Lake Helen
description: A high-altitude roadside lake sitting at the base of Lassen Peak with incredibly clear, blue water.
tips: Golden hour is best here as it lights up the high elevations of the peak above the lake

name: Emerald Lake
description: A small, clear alpine lake known for its stillness and reflections of the surrounding volcanic landscape.
tips: Visit at or shortly after sunrise for the calmest winds and best mirror reflections

name: Boiling Springs Lake Trail
description: A large, turquoise-blue geothermal lake that is one of the most unique features in the park.
tips: The lake's color is striking; capture it from the trail loop to show its scale

name: Summit Lake Trail
description: A small loop around a scenic lake that offers easy access to reflections of Lassen Peak.
tips: Best for early morning light on the water and the peak
Camping here allows for shooting directly from the campsite at first light

name: Reflection Lake Trail
description: True to its name, this lake offers some of the most picturesque reflections of Lassen Peak in the park.
tips: Ranked as one of the top three spots for picturesque peak-across-water compositions

name: Mill Creek Falls Trail
description: The tallest waterfall in the park, standing at twice the height of Kings Creek Falls.
tips: A hidden gem with low visitor traffic, perfect for undisturbed long-exposure shots
